item.title: espresso over ice with a little half and half
item.description: A simple recipe that you can order from your favorite barista: an espresso shot over ice. Leave enough room to add a spot of half and half. Cold, refreshing, and very strong. To try: a shot of espresso over shaved ice. I think this is doable at Ann Arbor Farmers Market where you’d go to the stall where a granny is selling shaved ice, and then walk a plain snow cone over to the Roos Roast stand for your espresso shot.

item.title: the hugo cookbook
item.description: Every technology for publishing eventually gets used to publish recipes. This collection of mine here is not an exception. I’ve marked up the recipes with the “recipe” category, and also created a “recipes” taxonomy with ingredients. It’s sort of like a subcategory but not really…well it is as long as I am careful about it. Previous attempts to do this include The Usenet Cookbook (from mod.recipes), alt.gourmand, and most favorite in my book the use of Gopher as a cookbook.

item.title: Mac and Goat
item.description: Mac and Goat calls for goat cheese; we generally use a goat gouda or a goat cheddar, both of which are usually available at the local Trader Joe’s. Feel free to substitute any hard cheese that melts well in your recipe. The dish also calls for rice pasta, but again feel free to substitute; you’re aiming for something like a rotini which handles the sauce well. Preheat oven to 375 degrees.

item.title: Chickpea, Potato and Tomato Stew: six recipes to mix and match from
item.description: Haven't cooked any of these yet, but there's some recipes to work through: Ricki Heller: Chickpea, Potato and Tomato Stew. Uses tahini to enrich the sauce. Fit Pregnancy: Chickpea, Potato and Tomato Stew with Chard . With chard, paprika, parsley. The First Mess: moroccan-style vegetable + chickpea stew . Sweet potatoes instead of potatoes, and a cinnamon+coriander+cumin spice. The Picky Eater: Indian Chickpea and Potato Stew. Curry is the flavor here, and cilantro replaces parsley.

item.title: recipe: tortilla casserole
item.description: This comes out kind of like a lasagna and is designed the same way: lots of layers. Ingredients: one package tortillas (whole wheat, corn, or flour) one can tomatoes with chiles one can black beans 1/2 jar corn relish one package shredded cheese assemble in layers, roughly as so: tortillas tomatoes with chiles tortillas beans cheese tortillas relish cheese Bake in a 350 degree oven; I left it in for about an hour, until the top was nicely browned and not singed.

item.title: Greek Lemon Roasted Potatoes
Recipe: Roasted broccoli salad with rice and feta
item.description: Roasted broccoli salad with rice and feta For the rice: prepare 1.5 cups rice according to your taste. Do this first. For the broccoli: Preheat oven to 425 degrees F. Cut a few heads of broccoli into bite sized florets. Mix in a bowl with olive oil, then place on a cookie sheet. Sprinkle sea salt on top. Roast 12-15 minutes until the broccoli is every so slightly browned on top.

item.title: Oven fried potato recipe
item.description: Writing this down so I remember this one detail: to get fries the right size, cut a medium potato into 16 pieces. (Cut in 4 equal width slices, then cut each slice into 4 parts). It works pretty quickly once you get going, and the resulting fries get crispy much more so than potatoes cut into quarters. A sweet potato yields 32 fries, cut in half and then in fours and then in fours).

item.title: Lentil, feta, and olive pasta salad
item.description: This delicious lentil, feta, and olive pasta salad is adapted from the cookbook The Best 125 Meatless Pasta Dishes by Mindy Toomay and Susann Geiskopf-Hadler, published by Prima Publishing in 1992. Add 3 cups of water to 1.5 cups of lentils in a saucepan on the stove. Add 2 bay leaves. Bring to a boil and then cook 25-35 minutes until the lentils are done. Rinse under cold water and drain.

item.title: Spicy sweet potato and black bean salad
item.description: The key here is "season to taste". We had more than 2 tsp of freshly made chipotle powder and I used it all, and it ended up being a bit more spicy than the normal food around our house (but still delicious). The recipe also calls for roasted pasilla peppers, which we didn't have so we didn't use them. I'm sure that any other roasted pepper would add to the flavor.

item.title: Kohlrabi and apple slaw - a study in comparative literature
item.description: This recipe is assembled from a variety of sources; I'll update when I've actually made it myself to report back. The basic idea is that you make a dressing of mayo thinned with a little vinegar, and you use equal part shredded kohlrabi and shredded apple in the salad. Mustard is a common seasoning. Some variations on the theme, with links to recipes: AllRecipes adds prepared mustard, lemon juice, and sugar to the dressing Epicurious replaces the mayo with heavy cream and adds some chopped parsley and mustard Boston Organics follows Epicurious but replaces parsley with mint The Floating Kitchen adds carrots, and replaces the mayo with Greek yogurt Martha Stewart dresses the slaw with olive oil and lemon juice and skips the mayo Edible Twin Cities adds some fennel to the salad I could continue but this is enough meta-information to head to the kitchen.

item.title: Recipe: Cole slaw
item.description: This recipe is easy and feeds a lot of people. I don't tend to measure, so you'll want to use proportions to your taste. One half head of green cabbage Four carrots Cider vinegar Mayo Salt Shred the cabbage using the slicing blade of your food processor. Put the cabbage in a large bowl. Shake some salt on top of the cabbage and mix it in. Trim the carrots and grate them using the grating blade of your food processor.

item.title: From Chekov's "Gooseberries"
item.description: Full text of Anton Chekov's "Gooseberries" is available at Eldritch Press. An excerpt from this short story: "But my point does not concern him so much as myself. I want to tell you what a change took place in me in those few hours while I was in his house. In the evening, while we were having tea, the cook laid a plateful of gooseberries on the table. They had not been bought, but were his own gooseberries, plucked for the first time since the bushes were planted.

item.title: Recipe: Asparagus with mushrooms
item.description: This simple asparagus with mushrooms dish is served with pasta. J doesn't like linguini, so we made it with rotini. This comes together in a hurry - you can cook the whole thing up in the time it takes to boil the pasta. Ingredients: Olive oil Two or three cloves of garlic Asparagus, about a pound Button mushrooms, about a pound Basil, dried or fresh White wine Preparation:

item.title: Expect the 2013 crop of juneberries to be a good one in Ann Arbor
item.description: That's the word from Ann Arbor Chronicle contributor Linda Diane Feldt: Service berries (aka June berries) appear to be on schedule. They taste like blueberries. Very edible. They will be ripe in two to three weeks [from May 23, 2013].  That puts a projected juneberry first picking date at about June 7, after the peonies start but before the u-pick strawberries are ready. More details on the Arborwiki Juneberries page.

item.title: Recipes, or information for everybody
item.description: This weblog has accumulated a number of recipes over time. Here's an index of sorts that makes it look like I've been writing a cookbook. (To be updated over time, as well.) Apple pancake "Dutch baby" Bi bim bap, a marinade for the vegetables Black bean tortilla casserole Blueberry and basil recipes Blueberry muffins with cardamom Burmese tea salad Butternut squash (AnnArbor.com) Coconut fried rice YUM Coconut squash soup, Molly's October Garlic Mustard for Earth Day (AnnArbor.

item.title: Coconut fried rice YUM
item.description: Disclaimer: This is not a low-fat dish. But it is delicious. Coconut fried rice Leftover rice Coconut oil Dessicated (dried) coconut flakes or powder Milk (I used almond milk to make this vegan) Sugar Heat oil in pan. Add leftover rice and dried coconut flakes. Mix and stir and cook. When the mixture is hot, add some milk. Sprinkle sugar on top to taste. Stir until hot; you'll know when it's done when the dried coconut doesn't taste dry.

item.title: Middle eastern red lentil soup
item.description: Originally from Kate and Lynne, this recipe depends on red lentils (not green lentils) and generally can be made with ingredients already in stock in our house. Serve with pita and labneh (if you can manage to not eat all of the pita and labneh before dinner), and with a chopped green salad with a sumac vinagrette. Middle Eastern Red Lentil Soup 1 medium yellow onion chopped 2 cloves of garlic, minced or pressed 1 T olive oil 1 and 1/2 C red lentils (NOT brown) 8 C water 1 t salt fresh ground pepper 1 T ground cumin lemon juice, to taste In a big pot, saute the onion and garlic in the olive oil until the onion is soft.

item.title: When the boys bring home trout from the trout farm, there's no question that it's trout for dinner.
item.description: The recipe for cooking the trout was simple: foil, lemon, and basil. It would have done well with a bit of olive oil or butter in the foil to bring out the flavor; it probably could have used some salt, in retrospect. The fish had been cleaned but not filleted. I don't have the tools or the knowledge to fillet a trout, but some people have it down pat; this video from "battlebauble" on YouTube looks convincing.

item.title: Green beans with walnuts
item.description: More recipes! This was a part of tonight's dinner. Oil for sauteing Garlic Walnuts, halves or pieces Green beans, trimmed Oregano Lemon juice Heat the oil in a large saucepan. Mince the garlic small, and add to the hot oil. Cook, stirring, until it smells great. Add the walnuts and stir fry until slightly browned or at least hot. Add the green beans and stir until coated with the oil.

item.title: Kedgeree, or something quite similar to it
item.description: I cooked this recipe - inspired by the recipes I found for Kedgeree - last night. I don't know what all of the boundaries are for an authentic recipe for this dish, which appears to have enough variety in the various descriptions of it that nearly anything with fish flaked into rice and spiced with Indian spices could be close. 2 cups rice cooked in 4 cups water safflower oil; some recipes call for ghee 1 onion, chopped small; garlic if you like it spices: curry powder, mustard seed, and similar vegetables: chopped tomatoes, peas, etc 2 tablespoons lemon juice salt, pepper fish: cooked or canned fish, fresh or smoked; we used canned boneless salmon greens: minced parsley or cilantro; dried OK in a pinch hard boiled eggs for garnish The method runs roughly as follows.

item.title: forking the cookbook
item.description: The github style of software development has, unusually, embraced the "fork" as a way of encouraging software use and reuse. Rather than being tied to a single repository owned by a single maintainer who accepts or rejects patches at their whims, you can easily fork an entire project in github and then work on it on your own. Notably this is not seen as treasonous even if it means that plans diverge.

item.title: October 2011 recipes: quince
item.description: I promised myself in October 2010 that I'd write about things just enough in advance to make them work so that I could have some things to make close at hand from fresh produce at Farmer's Market, and regretted that I didn't have quince recipes ready.   To remedy that, here's a few. Quince caramel from Chez Pim. Poach quinces in syrup, use the quince syrup to make caramels. I'm not a candy thermometer owner, but it does sound delicious.

item.title: rhubarb syrup, and what to make with it; and, conversely, how to avoid it
item.description: Working my way through the rhubarb recipe set, I find variations on what I made tonight, which was stewed rhubarb. If you were to separate the juice from the fruit, you'd get Rhubarb Syrup, as seen in the New York Times (water, vanilla pod, no sugar), The Kitchn (4c rhubarb, 1c sugar, 1c water, ginger root), Food in Jars (more sugar). Use as a flavoring in fizzy water, or in a fizzy drink.

item.title: delicious ketchup
item.description: As an exercise for wanting to keep enough bookmarks in delicious, or more likely its crowd of descendants, I provide to you some delicious ketchup. The problem with a general Google search for ketchup is that there is so much ketchup out there - so many recipes, so many products, so much Heinz everywhere. The delicious search for ketchup for me was a directed search; I knew that one of those interesting magazines that comes from New York City had a story about ketchup once, and how it was the perfect food.

item.title: Local, seasonal recipe guide
item.description: It's harvest time, which means there are a lot of recipes you can do with food that you can buy locally. One thing that would help that a lot is finding the people who buy the same stuff you do, and who share the same tastes, and who can work with you to figure out how to stock up so you have enough on your shelves always to get a meal on the table.

item.title: Black Bean Tortilla Casserole Recipe
item.description: This is the easiest possible black bean tortilla casserole that I could come up with. It is suitable for preparing ahead of time and putting in the oven with a timer. Adjust seasonings to taste. via www.grouprecipes.com I signed up for GroupRecipes a million years ago, in Internet time; it's still around. The tag line is "recipe discovery" and it has some really interesting ways of assembling a set of recipes that might be what you want to make so that you can go off on your own to make your own.

item.title: Basil and blueberry recipes, theme and variations
item.description: According to the search logs, it's season for both. Here's a bunch of recipes that use both. The common third ingredient is citrus, either lime or lemon, either in the recipe or served as the with. Lemon cupcakes with blueberry basil filling.  from the blog A Good Appetite: Blueberry Basil Sauce 1/3 cup frozen or fresh blueberries 1 T water 1/2 t lemon juice 1 1/2 T granulated sugar 6 large basil leaves, chopped Blueberry, basil and rum cocktail, Art of Drink:

item.title: Cauliflower Curry
item.description: Cauliflower Curry 1 Tbs canola oil 1 large onion, chopped 2 8 oz packages savory baked tofu curry powder 1 head cauliflower, cut into florets, steamed coconut milk, about half a can diced tomatoes, one small can Heat the canola oil over medium heat (6⁄10).  Add chopped onion. Cook until fragrant.  Add curry powder - I generally sprinkle it lightly over the top - and stir until even more fragrant and colorful.

item.title: Popcorn recipe, oil ripples, and Bénard-Marangoni convection
item.description: Popcorn canola oil popping corn Heat a sturdy deep pot with a lid to the same temperature you'd use for low temperature sauteing; on our stove it's 6 of 10.  When the pot is properly warmed up, pour a bit of oil on the bottom (about a tablespoon or a little more) and bring that up to heat.  I know it's at the right temperature when the thin layer of oil starts to form standing waves, ridges, or ripples.

item.title: Molly's October coconut squash soup
item.description: Recipe adapted from directions and shopping hints from Molly at Farmer's Market. Molly's October squash soup Ingredients: onion garlic ginger winter squash, peeled and diced (I used butternut and delicata) coconut milk diced tomatoes stock (vegetable or chicken) Saute onion, garlic, and ginger in olive or coconut oil.  Add the squash, cook until everything smells nice and the squash is a little bit browned.   Deglaze the pan with a little wine (I used rice wine), then add diced tomatoes, coconut milk, and hot stock.

item.title: Stuffed peppers with leftover grains recipe
item.description: The basic idea is from Martha Rose "Fast Vegetarian Feasts" 1986, p. 103.  It's very simple, as befits her normal cooking.  Cut the tops from peppers, clean them out, fill with a mix of leftover rice and beans and top with cheese.  Bake 30 to 40 minutes, as long as it takes for things to get as soft as you want. I'm guessing I'll end up using black beans; there's rice from yesterday.

item.title: Karnabeet recipe
item.description: Assembled from a few sources; not tried yet; this is approximate. Blanch cauliflower and saute in olive oil until browned. Make a lemon-tahini-garlic sauce. Mix.  Cook.   Serve sprinkled with sumac and parsley. Some alternatives: Vegetarian Times roasts the cauliflower instead of sauteing Drum Like A Vegan adds rosemary, also roasts instead of sautes Gastronomical Three reviews the late, lamented La Zamaan which added pomegranate seeds Kitchen Chick looks at Zamaan Cafe (2011) with a photo of Ali Hijazi's karnabeet For Monday.

item.title: purple beans for dinner; or, anthocyanin pigmentation in Phaseolus vulgaris
item.description: We had purple beans for dinner, from farmer's market.  I heated some olive oil in a pan and cooked them through until they had turned all green, and then salted them a little at the end. The recipe called for adding chopped almonds but it didn't happen; instead I served the boys tofu that I had cut into cubes and boiled (boiling it improves the texture quite a bit, firming it up more to my liking).

item.title: menu plan monday: first week of April
item.description: Some notes, more for myself than for you. Horseradish is now available at market; $4 for a jar from Grandma's Kitchen.  Grandma says hers is pure, not mixed with turnip as some would do.  Farmers Market had a lot of produce - field greens and flowers were the big new crops.  We had some tat soi from Shannon Brines that was very good in a stir fry. The phone on the farm in Homer, MI is answered only at 8am, if I read the handout right.

item.title: Blueberry muffins with cardamom; some recipes, in the hopes that summer will arrive
item.description: I'm just going to keep posting about blueberries until I'm sure it's going to be summer again; I think we have a few tubs still in the freezer. The search is for a blueberry muffin recipe with cardamom, and here's some sample of same, to see what the variety is in the recipes so that perhaps some meta-recipe will emerge.  Do be sure to read the first one through; it's a moving memorial and a story of how we celebrate the end of someone's life.

item.title: Menu plan Monday: second week of January
item.description: A second try at menu plan Monday, written Sunday night. Farmer's market on Saturday was eggs, apples, some good conversation and not much more food.  We didn't get there early enough for fresh greens from Brines Farm, and by the time we were there Wasem's was out of donuts.  Still a lot of fun. Food coop was pleasant, but I didn't do most of my shopping there.  Next week I'll do shopping for spices there, since their selection is best and they are never out of stock of anything.

item.title: Vegetarian "Green Goddess" dressing
bi bim bap - the marinade for the vegetables
item.description: Marinade for bi bim bap vegetables (carrots and spinach): 2 cloves garlic peeled 2 green onions 5 tablespoons soy sauce 2 tablespoons sugar 2 tablespoons vegetable oil 1 teaspoon sesame seeds 1 tablespoon sesame oil 1⁄8 teaspoon black pepper originally from Linda Sue Park’s Bee-Bim Bap!

item.title: Baked Polenta: "no-stir polenta sounds like no-water soup - possible but unlikely"
item.description: The family recipes for polenta all involve stirring for a long time, but I didn't want to do that.  This alternative approach showed up in a search for the delicious tag polenta, from the blog Hungry Cravings - the so called Cheater Method Polenta. The critics were skeptical: Vaguery: @vielmetti no-stir polenta sounds like no-water soup. Possible, but unlikely. Good luck! but it turned out fine - no stir is an exaggeration, more like one or two stirs but not more than that.

item.title: Radish salad with soy and sesame dressing
item.description: This is the simplest possible thing to make with a bunch of radishes fresh from farmers market ($1.25 this week). one bunch radishes vinegar soy sauce sesame oil Wash and trim the radishes.  Slice thin, put in a bowl.  Add vinegar (I used white vinegar, but rice vinegar would do well), soy sauce, and a little sesame oil; you're after enough to moisten, not to cover.  Let sit a few minutes before eating.

item.title: Scrambled eggs with slow roasted tomatoes (炒鸡蛋西红柿)
item.description: I did the slow roasting during high tomato season, and there are a few quarts of them in the freezer. Wondering which recipes would show up for a search for "recipe egg tomato" on Twitter, I ended up much to my surprise on a Beijing travel web site, which had a recipe for Fried Egg and Tomato – Chǎo Jīdàn Xīhóngshì – 炒鸡蛋西红柿. Egg and tomato might sound like an odd combination, but this is a really common Chinese dish which can be found on the menu at every cheap and cheerful Chinese eatery in Beijing.

item.title: Papaws, the Michigan banana
item.description: Paw paws go by lots of names: • Possumhaw • Dog-banana • Indian-banana • False banana • Custard-apple • Michigan banana • Hoosier banana • Ozark banana • Poor-man’s banana • Wild banana • Prairie banana • Nebraska banana • Indiana banana Zingerman's makes Paw Paw Gelato: One of the most exciting desserts this year is Paw Paw gelato. Last year I met someone who grows a large variety of Paw Paws and took my impression of them from this small wild-ish crop with limited yields to "how many do you want and what variety".

item.title: How to freeze berries
item.description: Wash, drain, then spread in a single layer on a cookie sheet.  Freeze until solid and then use a spatula to carefully scrape them (whole) into freezer bags or tubs. Label, carefully.  "Beans, do not open until February".  So that when it's February, you'll have something to look forward to, and so that the fridge monsters don't eat them before then.

item.title: Blueberry Buffalo stew
item.description:
Blueberry buffalo stew from Cooking Debauchery, via merathena on LJ:
The blueberries melt into the stock producing the most delectable, mahogany colored broth and a fragrance the fills the house with the scents of fall. We're vegetarians at home, so this is going to have to be someone else's potluck dish. There's buffalo raised in Michigan at Sprik Farms near Grand Rapids, and at TMZ Farm near Pinckney.

item.title: Strawberries are in for the 2008 season
item.description: via arborparents, a report that strawberries are in at Rowe's Produce Farm - head there from the Rawsonville Road exit, south to Martz Rd between Ypsi and Belleville. Price of strawberries is $1.43/lb. www.rowesproducefarm.com UPDATE: Peas too! Hello Rowe's Produce Farm customers, SUGAR SNAP PEAS ARE NOW READY TO BE PICKED!!!!! We opened our first field of sugar snap peas for picking today and they are LOADED. Now is the time to pick!

item.title: Potato pancakes (Latkes) recipe
item.description: This is the family latke recipe, perfected over time. Ten pounds of potatoes serves one neighborhood. Warning: the following recipe may be bad for your health and completely destructive of your kitchen! From a newspaper clipping in my recipe book, much amended by me over the years: POTATO PANCAKES Time: 20 minutes (More like two hours, unless you have multiple griddles) 2 large eggs 3 cups grated drained, all-purpose potatoes (see below) 1/4 cup grated onion (see below) 1 teaspoon salt, more to taste (less) 2 to 4 tablespoons matzo meal, or as needed (I used whole wheat flour; you could also use breadcrumbs) Canola oil, for frying Applesauce and sour cream for serving, optional (mandatory!

item.title: semolina pudding
item.description: January 26, 2003 SEMOLINA PUDDING Ingredients: 1 cup sugar 1 cup milk 4 cups water grated peel of 1 lemon (pref. organic) 1 cup semolina flour cinnamon raspberries or other berries Directions: Mix sugar, milk, water and lemon peel in a pot or big saucepan. Heat until just about to boil, then gradually sprinkle in semolina flour, whisking the whole time to prevent lumps from forming. Allow mixture to thicken considerably.

item.title: Orzo salad
item.description: repeated from a recipe blog I used to keep, from 2001. A very simple orzo salad. One pound orzo. 1 pint-size tub green olives 1 pint-size tub feta cheese 2 bunches parsley Cook the orzo and rinse with cold water to remove the starch and stop it from cooking. Pit the olives, reserving the juice they came in. (It is key to have good olives for this recipe - we get good ones at Whole Foods or (better) the food coop, "french provencal with herbs".
